articles.summary: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
articles.title: Your Thursday Briefing

articles.summary: After a recent assertion by the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, that he would never agree to a Palestinian state, the Palestinians can argue that they no longer have a negotiating partner.
articles.title: Palestinian Leaders See Validation of Their Statehood Effort

articles.summary: Prime Minister Habib Essid said that Tunisian authorities were working with other governments to learn more about the backgrounds and motives of the two gunmen.
articles.title: Tunisia Has Found No Terrorist Links to Gunmen in Museum Attack

articles.summary: Critics warn that President Vladimir V. Putin’s bargain to gain stability in Chechnya has unleashed an unpredictable despot in the region’s leader, Ramzan A. Kadyrov.
articles.title: Chechen’s Ties to Putin Are Questioned Amid Nemtsov Murder Case

articles.summary: Robert Dahl, who ran a struggling vineyard, and his chief investor, Emad Tawfilis, were supposed to be settling differences on Monday. They did not.
articles.title: A Vineyard Dispute, $800,000 in Cash, and Two Dead in Napa

articles.summary: The seeds for New Jersey state officials’ controversial decision to settle a long-running environmental pollution case for $225 million were planted as early as summer 2012.
articles.title: Christie Administration Deal With Exxon Was Years in the Making

articles.summary: The legislation would effectively set minimum weights for women and girls to work as models, a step that supporters say is necessary to combat the persistence of anorexia.
articles.title: French Parliament Debates Weight Standards for Fashion Models

articles.summary: A photographer shows how improvements in camera sensors and software and in postproduction software have made it possible to take excellent photos at night.
articles.title: Capturing the Night in Digital Photos, Spectacularly

articles.summary: Scoring is down. The game is slow. Players are bolting for the N.B.A. after a year. Many believe college basketball needs “an extreme makeover.”
articles.title: College Basketball Is an Attraction. Is It Pretty? Well ...

articles.summary: Critics say the designers’ views on in-vitro fertilization and family are out of fashion. But normally outspoken magazine editors aren’t saying anything.
articles.title: Dolce & Gabbana Comments Trigger Public Outrage ... and Uncomfortable Silence

articles.summary: The criticism on social media was so intense that the company’s chief communications officer temporarily deleted his Twitter account.
articles.title: Starbucks Initiative on Race Relations Draws Attacks Online

articles.summary: To run through the city’s medieval streets and working-class neighborhoods, where dissidents had conspired against Communist rule, is to run through Czech history.
articles.title: At the Prague Marathon, History Is a Spectator

articles.summary: International pressure and sanctions on a right-wing government is the only thing that will change Israel’s behavior.
articles.title: Netanyahu’s Win Is Good for Palestine

articles.summary: Donald Maloney, 60, who hailed from a family of New York mariners, died when his vessel, the Sea Bear, sank along the South Shore of Long Island.
articles.title: For Tug Captain, Job That Runs in Family Turns Deadly Off Long Island
